It was hard!! I have major stiffness issues and the twists always almost make me cry because I can barely do them. But I know if i keep going how good I'll feel, and how much easier it will be later. I forgive myself for not keeping up. I forgive myself for the mental turmoil I put myself through after getting sick and not being very patient.. I forgive myself for not being patient when I needed to do several variations to make it through today. Looking forward to tomorrow. 👑

Hi all, I started this series on March 6. Done yoga exercises before but wanted to do something special for myself, just having started retirement. I already love the slow, but powerful, flow of the sessions. A practical thing: How do you people avoid sliding on the mat in downward facing dog? I tried naked feet and then socks, but I feel I need to apply extra force just to remain in the pose. Any tricks out there for the best way?
I am in Denmark by the way.

It may take me all year to complete the 30 days but I just did day 5! Yay me! Oh and "my breath is my anchor, my anchor is my breath"....that has helped me realize how much I hold my breath and how shallow I breath due to stress.  Thank you for that golden mantra nugget!

I just started your online videos.I was missing my yoga studio and mat practice! I am enjoying your videos and like the length, your instructions, and the routines. Of course, I love Benji being a dog lover myself (a husky mom).  I am a long time yoga practitioner since my 20's. I am approaching 70 now and have adapted my practice to more gentler ones over the years. It took awhile to not judge myself when it was time for hip replacement and at first viewed the changes as "I used to do pigeon" or other poses as a failure on my part. I now teach adaptive accessible yoga with Lakshmi Voelker Chair Yoga and help other yogis and those who find getting up and down on the mat challenging.  Thank you for your guidance in getting back on the mat! I'm doing 2-3/week along with my basic sitting and standing daily routine with Eden Energy Medicine Yoga.. Thank you Adriene and Benji!

Adrienne, I just want to tell you, you’re an inspiration. In 2019, I was 230lbs and had to go on a drug to prevent diabetes since I was prediabetic. I began watching your videos and lost 97 lbs. now, with the quarantine and working from homes, I’ve gained 30 lbs back and had lost my routine. I began doing your 30 day yoga journey again and have lost 5 lbs in 5 days! I love you! What you do doesn’t just help me lose weight and build strength. I also find that starting my day off with you helps me to have a better day. My work ethic improves, I’m more patient with my son, and it sets the pace for me to succeed from dawn to dusk. Thank you for these videos and your YouTube channel! I love yoga, because of you.
@Sara Zonneveldt thank you! And thanks for checking on me. I love this community!
@Holly Harrison sounds great! I'm happy youre doing well :) x

@Sara Zonneveldt but just to give an example, today I had a scrambled egg over a half an avocado for breakfast (200 calories) a healthy choice steamer meal for lunch (290 calories) and what I cook for my son and boyfriend for dinner. Tonight it was Greek seasoned ground turkey over bow tie pasta with green beans (600 calories). So no eating disorder here. Promise. Just mindful eating. I track it all on my Fitbit and get my 64 Oz of water in per day.

@Sara Zonneveldt thanks for your concern but I’m great. A pound a day is good. I consume roughly 1200-1500 a day depending on the amount of calories I burn through yoga, cardio, etc, and I don’t snack between meals. To be honest, there’s no reason for me to have gained the weight I did bc my metabolism is fast.

Hi love, just randomly saw your comment and noticed that you said that you lost 5 lbs in 5 days. That's a lot of pounds in such a short amount of time. So I just wanted to check in on you and see if you're doing alright and to remind you that eating healthy and losing weight doesn't mean that you have to starve yourselve, because you deserve food and you deserve to eat. Food is fuel, after all! Hope youre having a great day :) x

I guess this isn't for everyone.  I "sort of" got through the "30 days with Adriene" and thought I would then try this Breath 30 days, but surprisingly it is for me way too hard and frustrating.  Too difficult to hear and understand her and when I do look up she is 3 poses ahead.  I really suck at the poses also, and although I know I only need to do what I can, when one is so far off, it tends to be too frustrating to keep trying something that is way too difficult.  I'm going to give up on this Breath voyage and maybe try some of her other videos for runners or climbers or left-handed chess players or whatever, or maybe try the original 30 days again and see if I can find something that isn't just exhausting and straining and frustrating  I've never been flexible so this isn't much of a surprise, but I hoped it would help with range of motion.  Maybe it has a little, but too little to really tell after just some 5-6 weeks or so.  Anyway, hopefully i am the rare duck that doesn't fit in here and everyone else is doing great and really happy and energized.  It sounds like it from the other responses.  Be well, everyone!

I’ve been forced to stop working or being active at all due to a fever of unknown origin during this pandemic.  After months of barely being able to stand long enough to do dishes, I’m finally trying to work on my stamina and begin to cope with fatigue.  I used to be one of the most active people I knew, and this whole thing has been a huge hit to that part of my identity.  Though I can’t do these videos every day because of the fever and fatigue, the gentle way she invites you back makes it feel like it’s okay.  In a way, her commentary makes it okay to be forgiving of myself and the new limitations my body has.  That I’m listening to what my body can handle, and that is the best I can do right now for it.  That kind of forgiveness is invaluable in allowing me to cope with these strange new limitations, and I’m sure it’s like that for everyone, regardless of your situation.

When you feel like you're not good enough or you're not seeing the results you want, please read this. This is my 3rd time in the last 3 months starting a YWA 30 day practice -- and I cannot stress how much more meaningful these practices get as time goes on. I was thinking during my practice today about how much yoga meant to me when I first started dabbling at the end of 2019 -- how it opened me up spiritually and made me feel alive in a way ive never felt in my brief 19 years on this planet. It took a while for me to get to the point of daily practices and then to 30 day consistent practices -- and thats when it started getting tough and lose its shine, but I knew it was good for me, a spiritual vegetable id avoided for a long time, so I stuck with it. The 2nd go round was easier in the sense my muscles were more toned, but it was harder to feel connected in that beautiful and fulfilling way like I first felt, and a lot of the time i felt like my mind was against me. And when this 3rd cycle first started, I wondered if this was all there is, the luster of a new activity finally good and dull.

But no. I was so wrong. I can feel that connection coming back. I can feel the hard work paying off as my mind begins to bend and strengthen in the most loving and sustainable way. As I was in the squat twisted to the right, I felt my legs on fire, and where before I would've wanted to straighten and relieve myself, this time I thought to myself and to all of you practicing -- "I know it hurts, but youre right there, you are getting stronger, you are not alone, keep holding on, dont give up!" And I had the most genuine smile on my face as we all released and sank into a forward fold.

There were times in the last 2 cycles of 30 day practices id feel so drained and unmotivated, I wouldn't do yoga that day or maybe several days, and I let myself do it. Perfectionistic guilt would try to eat at me, but I felt it didn't matter when I got back on the mat, it just mattered that I came back because I wanted to, and not because I was obligated. And I knew that if I came replenished and ready on my time, I'd enjoy it more, and I did.

So I encourage you: let yourself have a day or more if you feel you really need it. There is no shame in saying, not today. Youre listening to your body and aligning with a compassionate understanding. You will come back, and you will be happier you did it. And over time, you may find that you need less and less breaks from yoga, but don't force it. Give yourself the gift of time. You will get there.

The mat, a training place, learning, practicing, and gaining strength. Taking it all to my daily journey, my interaction with the world. Today, more than ever so far, the acquired knowledge and skills from practicing yoga and mediation were intentionally applied to help me through the dark events in the nation and the hurt, fear, and infirmity of those I encountered in the ER.
Are we, as a nation, going to heal after today? Are we going to connect? I feel a deep sadness for us.
Practicing Replinish before facing the day was the best part of my day which prepared me to face what was not expected or imaginable. Refilled, restored, reloaded to face an unexpectedly hard day with deeper breath that gives rise to balance, strength, and a calmed mind.
It is difficult today to find the mundane gifts, to find what to be thankful for yet if I look carefully there is much to thank for today in the midst of this trauma. Thankful today for Yoga with Adriene, for today's practice, a safe and healthy space to Replenish.
How do I hug my ribs?? What does she mean?

two things today:
1. I just started a new job this week & had 2 big meetings today. When I started to panic, without even realizing I was doing it, I started to breathe deeply. I continued this until the anxiety in my chest loosened up. Wow.
2. In downward dog today I realized when Adriene said we can lift our heels that mine were naturally resting on my mat — I can do this now?!!? PROGRESS! ❤️
definitely needed a yoga practice after todays events. Day 5 down!

Thank you Adriene. This was a wonderful treat after a really stressful and chaotic day. I so appreciate the work you do to create these challenges. Today's was perfect!

This probably sounds kinda weird, but I closed my eyes during the eagle-arms portion of this practice and didn't open them again until it was finished. And during that time, I suddenly visualized myself in a different place - a different room, a different house, a different time of day. I kept my eyes closed because I didn't want to break the illusion, because it was so peaceful and slow and quiet. That's never happened to me before during a practice, but I welcomed it and welcomed my return home when it was finished. Not sure if anyone else has experienced anything similar, but it was nice.💜

I hope that everyone practising today had a good session, especially those people who are physically struggling like me, but still doing their best to keep up with the lesson / practice, in their own way. Namaste all! 🙏😊🦋👯🌈💖🧜‍♀️

Lesson, don't judge, just experience.  Much continued love for you and the entire community.  I'm friggin hooked!

I had a rough day. I didn't even change my pj's and just sat in bed and watched four 2 hour movies (from the 50s and 60s). I wanted to escape reality so I shut my curtains and let myself be lost in the movies for a day. I didn't want to get on the mat, but it was still rolled out from yesterday's practice and I remembered that the important thing was to show up, even if I'd end up in child pose for half an hour. but once on the mat, it became easy to just move with the breath and my eyes closed, guided by Adriene's voice.  I guess what you should take from this is that it's important to just show up, even standing still is part of the journey if that's what your body needs.

Day 5: okay, so today sucked and I said some VERY rude things to Adriene and also myself in the privacy of my home, which is unfair and I'm very glad she didn't hear them. Sometimes yoga goes like that.

I have the most trouble, I think, when I don't understand what sort of position I'm supposed to be moving into. There was a lot of pausing the video and clicking back, sometimes multiple times, to figure out what was going on. There was a lot of not feeling like I had time to listen to my breathing and my body because I had to worry about trying to understand what I was meant to do next. There was a lot of feeling out of sync, and getting way more out of sync as I tried to catch up.

Which begs the question: why is it so important to me to catch up? Why is it so important that I do every single step and every single pose of every single practice, so much so that I get mad at myself and my very kind yoga instructor if I ever miss a beat? If I hate pausing and clicking back and getting out of the flow to stop and figure things out and then having to start up again, then what's wrong with just keeping going and getting back into it a few beats later?

It's yoga. Doing some of it is better than doing none of it. There is no grand high Yoga Council watching me try to pass a Yoga Test that says I must complete every single element. And yet I still feel like, if I don't get all of today's practice RIGHT, or at least mostly right, then I won't improve enough for the future and then I won't be able to do tomorrow's practice, or next week's, or next month's.

Today we are noticing feelings, and those are the feelings I'm noticing. They exist. I'm writing them down. Tomorrow we will notice different feelings, and maybe they'll be better or maybe they'll be worse, but they're feelings. And it's good to have a name for them.

And they're a little better now.

@Hearts Love Oh my god, I think 'skip ahead and watch how things are done before you start a new video' might actually be life-changing advice. It's so incredibly simple. It fixes so much. THANK YOU.

And thanks for your kind words of support in general. I started keeping track of my reactions to practice down in the comments threads on Day 1 as a way to sort out my own responses, not necessarily expecting anyone else to care. I knew there'd be days that ended in total frustration, but it means a lot to hear I'm not alone. (Which I KNEW--always refresh for the video counter!--but is still very nice.) <3 Thank you!

Hey, if you are new to yoga, this is definitely a lot! This might sound like a lot of effort, but i actually do it when i want to see what poses will be used in a new video. Skip ahead and watch how the poses are done. But definitely, just hang in there. If you stop a pose halfway, that is fine. You can always come to mountain pose (standing) or child pose if you are a bit off, or stop on squats, with hands in prayer if the arm position is too complicated. These are new poses and terms for you. There were a few I wasn’t sure about, and i did yoga for several years (but several years ago....much stiffness!). Focus on working on improving the basics, like downward dog and your posture there, rather than all the twists. Its a journey, so enjoy this one, rather than try to do everything 100%. As time goes on, you will find many of these basics, like warrior, plank, downward dog are the basis to the others. Hugs to you!

New shapes for me today. Some lil bit of shakes, but feeling calm and peaceful after. Trying to use my “Uji” breath throughout, doing pretty good. Growing my strength, my connection with my breath, my practice. “My breath is my anchor; my anchor is my breath.”

Only 5 days in and my posture is improving, as I am growing my strength and awareness. 😍

I look forward to waking up these days. First order business is turning on the heat to warm the room I practice in. I make tea. Come back into the now-warm room. Roll out my mat. Go to my email with joy (what?!) because I know there will be grounding, beautiful words in there to greet me. Press play. Connect to my breath and anchor myself here and now, taking time to check in with myself. Take a minute to scroll through these comments and read other people write out exactly how I am feeling. Take my phone off airplane mode and greet the day with my cup filled, ready to serve others. Thank you for creating this space and this experience Adriene, we love you!!!

Hey yoga with andriene,
Could I ask for some advice. I have right sided hemiplegia which is a form of cerebral palsy meaning I have a weakness on the right side of my body. I am unsure how to approach some poses such as tree pose or side plank or poses that require weight bearing on the right. I can do some pose on my left side. I would love to some day be any to do them, as it would be a big achievement
Could I ask for some advice for how to adapt or replace poses to still build strength on the right side?
@Yoga With Adriene thank you😃
Hi Tilly! It's advisable to check with your doctor or PT first, but maybe keeping a chair or using  a wall nearby that you can put some of your weight on would help. x

I've been wrestling with a crazy muscle pudding in the back for the last like 6 months, that's been causing me lots of pain/troubles. I'm seeing physios, massos etc. It improves, but slowly.

Yoga has probably helped too - not that it's a cure-all (I had so much tension that I really do think I needed some specialized help to get ride of it). However it's a great tool to help me monitor the improvements and how things evolve. Especially with all the reminder to be very conscious of our posture, of how we place our feet/hands/legs/etc. I feel like my perception of the thousands of little peculiarities of my bodies is much better. I am confident this will help me avoid a rerun of that episode, and not get into huge imbalances like that in the first place.

That’s great that you are taking the time to relieve and treat the pain and tension. I know that before I started doing yoga and going to an osteopath that I had kind of just accepted that my shoulders were super tight etc and that’s just how it would always be.

I hope that your journey continues to move forward and that you experience less pain!

I always love that gorgeous Sphinx Pose, a feeling of grace, then that awesome shoulder stretch, correcting our Mr Burns 😂 I was a little trembly in that last but one downward dog, meeting my edge, so I relaxed into a child’s pose when it came to the ‘one-arm’ downward dog, I need more arm strength for that one. But I met on our bellies for the cooling down rest and all was good. I’m really enjoying our adventure, never knowing what’s coming next and trusting you Adriene to guide us along the way 🧘🏼‍♀️🧘🏻‍♀️🙏💕

Aww loved this, thanks Adrienne! As just woke up, I had to stretch a lil extra to match your pace. Also, to anyone that is heavier than average, don’t feel bad if it’s hard on your wrists. Adapt the moves to seated or stood. You are holding up a lot more that our slim yogi here. I no way could lift one hand in down dog, as can only just do it with two hands! Don’t let it put you off, plenty still to be gained from yoga and this breath journey. Similar if you have a larger chest, you physically won’t get your arms round as far, as two bossoms in the way! Or laying on front might be uncomfortable cos can’t get head to floor. Don’t worry about the poses, keep the breath and intention, and modify. It’s your body & practice. Much love 💚💚💚
